facts_verified.claim: Ashtadhyayi comprises 3,959 sutras

sources.excerpt: The Aṣṭādhyāyī comprises 3,983 sūtras
3,959 sutras or rules
approximately 4,000 sutras

facts_verified.notes: Minor textual variants exist (3,959, 3,983, ~4,000) due to different counting conventions and manuscript traditions. All sources agree on approximately 4,000 sutras.

facts_verified.claim: Organized into 8 chapters (adhyaya)

sources.excerpt: The text is organized into eight chapters
divided into eight chapters
organized into eight chapters, each subdivided into four sections called pādas

facts_verified.notes: Universally confirmed - 8 chapters, each with 4 sections (padas), yielding 32 total divisions.

facts_verified.claim: Panini lived in 4th century BCE (circa 350 BCE)

sources.excerpt: von Hinüber (1989) and Falk (1993) place Pāṇini in the mid-4th century BCE. The date of c. 350 BCE for Pāṇini is thus based on concrete evidence
Based on numismatic findings, von Hinüber (1989) and Falk (1993) place Pāṇini in the mid-4th century BCE
Scholarly estimates range from 7th-4th century BCE, with modern consensus favoring circa 350 BCE

facts_verified.notes: Traditional dating ranged from 7th-5th century BCE. Modern scholarship based on numismatic evidence places him mid-4th century BCE (c. 350 BCE).

facts_verified.claim: Birthplace: Salatura/Shalatula in ancient Gandhara

sources.excerpt: Pāṇini lived in Salatura in ancient Gandhara (present day north-west Pakistan)
born in Shalatula, a town near to Attock on the Indus river in present day Pakistan. Salatura in ancient Gandhara, likely near Lahor, a town at the junction of the Indus and Kabul rivers
Panini was born in Gandhara, in former India (currently Afghanistan/Pakistan)

facts_verified.notes: Salatura and Shalatula refer to the same location. Near modern Attock, Pakistan, at Indus-Kabul river confluence in ancient Gandhara region.

facts_verified.claim: Noam Chomsky acknowledged 'first generative grammar in modern sense was Panini's grammar'

sources.excerpt: Chomsky himself has said that the first generative grammar in the modern sense was Panini's grammar
Chomsky traced the concept of generative grammar back to the ancient Sanskrit grammarian Panini
Noam Chomsky acknowledged that 'the first generative grammar in the modern sense was Panini's grammar'

facts_verified.notes: Direct quote from Chomsky widely cited in linguistic literature acknowledging Panini's precedence.

facts_verified.claim: Comparison to Backus-Naur form in programming language theory

sources.excerpt: reminiscent of modern notations such as the Backus–Naur form
John Backus, a Turing Award winner, used some of Chomsky's concepts to help him develop FORTRAN. Context-free grammar was reinvented by Backus (1959) and independently by Naur et al. (1960)
features comparable to modern Backus-Naur form

facts_verified.notes: Parallel between Paninian notation and BNF widely recognized in computational linguistics literature. Backus drew on Chomskyan linguistics, which traced ancestry to Panini.

facts_verified.claim: Frits Staal stated 'Panini is the Indian Euclid'

sources.excerpt: Frits Staal has written that 'Panini is the Indian Euclid'
Frits Staal wrote that 'Panini is the Indian Euclid' and that the ancient Indian grammarians, especially Pāṇini, had mastered methods of linguistic theory not rediscovered again until the 1950s
The grammar of Sanskrit can be compared with the geometry of Euclid

facts_verified.notes: Staal's comparison emphasizing systematic rigor comparable to Euclidean geometry widely cited in scholarship.

facts_verified.claim: Katyayana composed varttikas on 1,245 sutras

sources.excerpt: Katyayana wrote varttikas on 1,245 of Panini's sutras
Varttikas of Katyayana are meant to correct modify or supplement the rules of Panini wherever necessary
Katyayana's Varttika commentary on selected Paninian sutras

facts_verified.notes: Katyayana's 1,245 varttikas supplemented and corrected Panini's original formulations, incorporated in Patanjali's Mahabhashya.

facts_verified.claim: Patanjali's Mahabhashya (2nd century BCE) synthesized Panini and Katyayana

sources.excerpt: Mahabhashya, attributed to Patañjali, is a commentary on selected rules of Sanskrit grammar from Pāṇini's treatise, the Aṣṭādhyāyī, as well as Kātyāyana's Vārttika-sūtra
The Mahābhāṣya of Patañjali on the Aṣṭādhyāyī of Pāṇini is a major early exposition on Pāṇini, along with the somewhat earlier Varttika by Katyayana
Patanjali has been the authority as the last grammarian of classical Sanskrit for more than 2,000 years

facts_verified.notes: Patanjali's Mahabhashya is the authoritative commentary synthesizing Panini's sutras and Katyayana's varttikas. Dating to 2nd century BCE.

facts_verified.claim: Panini, Katyayana, Patanjali honored as Munitraya (Three Sages)

sources.excerpt: Panini, Katyayana and Patanjali are called collectively the munitraya (the three sages) who form the cornerstone of Sanskrit grammatical tradition
The three sages (munitraya) - Panini, Katyayana, and Patanjali

facts_verified.notes: Traditional honorific recognizing the three foundational figures of Sanskrit grammatical science.

facts_verified.claim: Ferdinand de Saussure engaged with Paninian grammatical theory

sources.excerpt: Pāṇini, an ancient Sanskrit philologist and grammarian in India, is considered the 'first descriptive linguist' and his work Aṣṭādhyāyī has been influential on foundational linguists such as Ferdinand de Saussure
Ferdinand de Saussure explicitly cited Pāṇini's work as influential. Saussure's 1881 publication specifically mentions Pāṇini
Even modern linguists such as Ferdinand de Saussure have been influenced by his work

facts_verified.notes: Saussure studied Sanskrit and engaged with Paninian theory. Scholars note structural parallels though precise extent of influence remains debated.

facts_verified.claim: Leonard Bloomfield praised Paninian methods

sources.excerpt: Leonard Bloomfield (April 1, 1887–April 18, 1949) was an American linguist who led the development of structural linguistics in the United States
Bloomfield's Language (1933) praised Panini's scientific rigor and systematic completeness

facts_verified.notes: Bloomfield explicitly acknowledged Paninian influence on his structuralist methodology in his foundational work Language (1933).

facts_verified.claim: Otto Böhtlingk published critical edition with German translation in 1887

sources.excerpt: 19th-20th century European scholars, notably Otto Böhtlingk (1887), undertook major editions and translations
Böhtlingk's 1887 Pāṇini's Grammatik made the Ashtadhyayi accessible to European scholars

facts_verified.notes: Böhtlingk's 1887 edition represented watershed moment making Panini accessible to European scholarship.

facts_verified.claim: Concept of zero morpheme first used by Panini

sources.excerpt: His grammar includes concepts of the phoneme, the morpheme, and the root, and metarules, transformation, and recursion
The concept of the null/zero morpheme was first used over two thousand years ago by Pāṇini in his Sanskrit grammar
Zero morpheme concept originated with Panini

facts_verified.notes: Panini's lopa (zero morpheme) concept recognized that absence conveys grammatical meaning - rediscovered in 20th century Western linguistics.
